explanation:
Each listed symbol can affect control flow or externally observable behaviour of thread_main_handle_connection and so is needed to judge whether any executed statements in that function are truly dead (i.e. removable without changing behaviour):

- MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_current_thread_ID_: sets thread ID state — side effect that may be observable; removal could change behaviour.
- MHD_D_IS_USING_POLL_: decides runtime path (select vs poll); influences which code is executed and which blocks could be dead.
- MHD_add_to_fd_set_: modifies fd_sets; determines whether select/poll will block or return — removing calls could change behaviour.
- MHD_itc_r_fd_, daemon->itc, MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_, MHD_itc_clear_, MHD_itc_activate_: inter-thread communication FD and helpers affect wakeup semantics and ordering; their behaviour determines whether select/poll-related code is meaningful.
- MHD_SYS_select_, MHD_sys_poll_: blocking APIs used — their semantics (return values, error handling) determine whether retry/continue/break paths are reachable.
- MHD_socket_get_error_, MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_EINTR_, MHD_SCKT_LAST_ERR_IS_, MHD_socket_strerr_, MHD_socket_last_strerr_: errno/last-error helpers affect error handling branches; needed to know if error branches are reachable/observable.
- MHD_DLOG: logging has observable side-effects (output) in many builds; removal might be considered behavioural change depending on requirements.
- MHD_update_last_activity_: updates timeouts/last-activity — side effects that influence later behaviour (timeouts), so cannot be assumed dead without its semantics.
- connection_get_wait: computes wait time used to set timeouts; affects whether timeout-related code executes.
- call_handlers: central dispatcher that can change connection state and perform I/O; its side effects make many subsequent branches reachable or not.
- MHD_connection_handle_idle: processes queued responses and state transitions; required to know if its invocation is necessary for correct behaviour.
- thread_main_connection_upgrade, MHD_resume_connection, daemon->notify_completed, con->urh, con->rq.client_aware, con->rq.client_context: upgrade-related code causes an early return and state transitions; whether that block is reachable and its side effects must be known.
- MHD_connection_close_, con->state, MHD_CONNECTION_CLOSED: connection-close semantics and constants determine cleanup and whether final close/cleanup code is reachable and observable.
- MHD_destroy_response, con->rp.response: response destruction has observable resource-management side effects; removing it could leak resources or change behaviour.
- shutdown, con->socket_fd, SHUT_WR (implicit): system shutdown of socket is observable at OS level; needed to determine whether that code is dead.

- Constants and event flags (MHD_NO, FD_SETSIZE, MHD_INVALID_SOCKET, POLLIN, POLLOUT, POLLERR, POLLHUP, MHD_POLL_EVENTS_ERR_DISC, MHD_POLL_REVENTS_ERR_DISC, MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_*): these values control switch/case, FD/poll masks and comparisons; their definitions determine which branches are feasible.

In summary: to decide if any statement in thread_main_handle_connection is dead, the next analyst must know the exact semantics and side effects of the listed functions, the values of the listed fields and constants (including whether compile-time flags select poll vs select and whether upgrade/HTTPS support is enabled). Without these symbols and semantics you cannot prove that executing a code region has no effect on program behaviour.
